quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: being a CEO or founder makes it slightly harder, uh, in some ways, because you still have to put on this mask.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Highlights the leadership reality that founders must manage their own emotions while projecting steadiness to others.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You have to put on this space of confidence externally and- and internally as well, where people need to trust you.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A practical reminder that trust often depends on consistently communicated confidence, not just competence.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You also don't want to subject them to the same anxiety that you're feeling and be a 100% transparent.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Offers a counterintuitive boundary on transparency: leaders should filter stress to avoid spreading anxiety through the team.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their platform lets you focus on growth rather than getting bogged down in subscription infrastructure.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical build-vs-buy principle: offload commodity infrastructure so teams can prioritize growth work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: RevenueCat is your source of truth for customer status across platforms and provides out of the box analytics for key subscription metrics like monthly recurring revenue, lifetime value, retention, and more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Emphasizes the operational value of a single source of truth plus standardized metrics for subscription businesses.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Well, based on our data, about a third of people will consider switching to another company after just one bad experience during onboarding.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: A concrete data point quantifying how costly onboarding failures can be for retention and churn risk.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I've consistently seen that improving onboarding is one of the highest leverage opportunities for both sign-up conversion and increasing longterm retention.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization guidance: treat onboarding improvements as a high-ROI lever across the funnel.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's because flawless data onboarding acts like a catalyst to get them and their customers where they need to go faster.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: A memorable mental model framing data onboarding as a speed multiplier for customer value realization.

quotes.topic_title: Being recognized and public tech celebrity moments
quotes.text: I actually do wonder subconsciously if I grew my hair out to avoid being recognized.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A counterintuitive example of how public visibility can subtly change behavior and identity-management choices.

quotes.topic_title: Being recognized and public tech celebrity moments
quotes.text: somebody turns around and says, “Is that the Product Hunt guy?”
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A concrete early moment that made “being recognizable” real, illustrating how quickly a personal brand can follow you into non-work settings.

quotes.topic_title: Being recognized and public tech celebrity moments
quotes.text: And that was the first time that sort of happened in that setting where I was like, oh gosh, now I have to like, think about my actions. And I can't just like, be entirely like loose and, you know, relax with my friends.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Highlights the practical tradeoff of visibility: it can impose constant self-monitoring that affects how you show up socially.

quotes.topic_title: Being recognized and public tech celebrity moments
quotes.text: And so when you combine that with, “Oh, these strangers might be watching me,” is not the best thing in the world, but it's okay.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of the anxiety cost of public exposure—and a grounded way to normalize it without catastrophizing.

quotes.topic_title: Being recognized and public tech celebrity moments
quotes.text: I'm an introvert though. So by hour, like three or four, I'm just like, ugh… uh… I need to use the restroom cause I haven't been able to escape and I'm socially exhausted, so, but they are fun.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A specific, practitioner-relevant data point for planning events/meetups: introverts often hit a hard energy limit after ~3–4 hours and need escape hatches.

quotes.topic_title: What people don’t know: moving to Miami
quotes.text: I moved to Miami about a year ago and, uh, I haven't been talking about it publicly, primarily because I just didn't want to be lumped into, oh, another person moving to Miami.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A contrarian take on choosing what to share publicly—opt out of trends/labels when there’s no upside.

quotes.topic_title: What people don’t know: moving to Miami
quotes.text: we’re- we're there about two thirds of the year, so I'm actually in California right now.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A concrete example of designing a flexible living setup rather than committing to a single location year-round.

quotes.topic_title: What people don’t know: moving to Miami
quotes.text: fortunately we have the flexibility, uh, when I say we, my girlfriend, Susie, and I, to just carry our laptops and work anywhere.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that remote work enables intentional lifestyle design—optimize location around seasons and preferences.

quotes.topic_title: What people don’t know: moving to Miami
quotes.text: so the way I describe ci- cities are kinda like a product.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A memorable framework: evaluate where to live using product-thinking rather than identity or hype.

quotes.topic_title: What people don’t know: moving to Miami
quotes.text: And so, you know, in terms of costs, there's cost of living in terms of housing, uh, food, taxes, a bunch of things that go into the cost of living in the city. And then the city provides a lot of benefits and- and things like that.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A practical cost/benefit model for comparing cities (inputs like taxes + outputs like benefits) to make a clearer decision.

quotes.topic_title: Opening Twitter DMs for founder advice
quotes.text: I opened it up quietly and, um, actually didn't get a lot of spam, uh, surprisingly. Like yeah, people would shill something or promote something, but it wasn't too bad.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway that opening DMs may not create the spam flood founders fear, lowering the barrier to trying it.

quotes.topic_title: Opening Twitter DMs for founder advice
quotes.text:
And part of it's because it just takes so long to write.
And sometimes I don't feel like inspired by any topic. It’s- it's sort of like a writer's block. And so I found this also kind of as a means to like, do micro- almost like micro blog posts in a way, uh, where the prompt is the question from somebody else. I don't have to think about the pr- prompt.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A practical content/learning system: use inbound questions as prompts to overcome writer’s block and publish consistently.

quotes.topic_title: Opening Twitter DMs for founder advice
quotes.text: And then the answer is- is in some ways, a way for me to actually think about that- that topic, almost like refine my own thinking in, in some sense.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Mental model: answering others’ questions doubles as a structured way to clarify and improve your own thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Opening Twitter DMs for founder advice
quotes.text: These are strangers, founders who DM me saying, “Hey, I’m- we have three months runway left. We’re running out of money. Here's a situation. What advice do you have?”
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Concrete example of the kind of high-stakes, candid problems people will share privately that they won’t ask publicly.

quotes.topic_title: Opening Twitter DMs for founder advice
quotes.text: And so the reality is that's not the case. Like [laughs] if you peered inside of almost every single company, it probably looks chaotic in- in different ways.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A reality-check observation that challenges the “everything is under control” founder narrative and normalizes internal chaos.

quotes.topic_title: Lenny’s newsletter format and writing workload
quotes.text: … And that ends up forcing you to have like concrete, actionable advice.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical writing/product-thinking tactic: anchor content (or guidance) in real questions to force specificity and actionability.

quotes.topic_title: Lenny’s newsletter format and writing workload
quotes.text: I've always liked your format by the way, in that you are, um- you're a curator in many sense. Like- yeah, you have a lot of experience and good ideas, but you're not trying to answer all the questions in that you are really pulling in experts in their domain expertise to like find answers or inspiration.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A curation-first model for producing better answers: don’t be the sole expert—systematically pull in domain experts to improve quality and breadth.

quotes.topic_title: Lenny’s newsletter format and writing workload
quotes.text: So I wanted to do this, like, “What does everyone do? And what seems to be the pattern of the things that work?” And that kind of led to this approach.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Describes a pattern-mining methodology: look across many examples to identify what consistently works rather than overfitting to one company’s story.

quotes.topic_title: Lenny’s newsletter format and writing workload
quotes.text: I say- I'd say the, uh, median post is about 10 hours. It's like, maybe I kind of work on it through the week. So maybe, like a few days through the week, but the most epic posts take hundreds and hundreds of hours that I kind of work on behind the scenes as I work on the weekly posts.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete workload benchmark that sets expectations for research-heavy writing and shows how long-term “epic” work can run in parallel with weekly output.

quotes.topic_title: Lenny’s newsletter format and writing workload
quotes.text: And so I- the first draft actually is maybe like 20 or 30% of the time. And then the rest is refining it and getting feedback and everything else.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A process model for high-quality writing: most effort should be allocated to revision and feedback, not just drafting.

quotes.topic_title: Should you start a startup and raise money
quotes.text: I do- I do spend time, ironically, like. challenging founders sometimes when they're thinking about raising or thinking about an idea to- to not raise.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Contrarian advice to resist the default impulse to fundraise and treat raising as a deliberate, high-stakes choice.

quotes.topic_title: Should you start a startup and raise money
quotes.text: However, I think it's super important that founders see a line of sight to work on this for ... I think my rule of thumb is a decade, just do you see yourself working on this for a decade?
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A practical litmus test for commitment that helps founders evaluate whether an idea is worth the long grind.

quotes.topic_title: Should you start a startup and raise money
quotes.text: And they skip to that step without just tinkering and building and, you know, Product Hunt, we called it, not even a side project, we called it an experiment.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Reframes early startup work as low-pressure experimentation rather than prematurely “starting a company.”

quotes.topic_title: Should you start a startup and raise money
quotes.text:
And that framing I think, is for me, has always been helpful because it's an experiment is really not about success. Of course you want it to be successful, but the goal is not success.
I put that in quotes, it's really to learn and, you know, see if people want this thing and then kind of adapt.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: An experimental mindset prioritizes learning and iteration over outcome-obsession, guiding how to validate ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Should you start a startup and raise money
quotes.text: So with- with Product Hunt, it was a side project in the beginning. It wasn't actually intended to be a startup at all, but in the beginning, you know, it was a newsletter, then it was a website and it was about four to five months before we even incorporated.And we got a lot of traction.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A concrete example of delaying incorporation and treating the product as a side project while proving traction first.

quotes.topic_title: Would Ryan raise again for Product Hunt
quotes.text: So at the time, this is also the thing I ask [laughs] founders is why do you need to raise money? Like, what is it for? Surprisingly, some people like- I don't know, like they don't have a clear answer.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic question for founders to clarify the concrete purpose of fundraising before pursuing it.

quotes.topic_title: Would Ryan raise again for Product Hunt
quotes.text: And when you're building a company, you probably don't want to innovate on too many things, um, including like essentially how to build a product and build a team.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A constraint-based strategy: reduce novelty in execution so you can focus innovation where it matters most.

quotes.topic_title: Would Ryan raise again for Product Hunt
quotes.text: So today it might be a little bit different in which I might not raise venture capital because Product Hunt isn't the type of company that needs to raise a ton of money.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A counterpoint to default VC thinking: funding strategy should match the company’s actual capital needs and business type.

quotes.topic_title: Would Ryan raise again for Product Hunt
quotes.text: Mm-hmm .Yeah, especially if it’s… I mean, I think it's very important to raise- raise from people who are aligned with you too. Meaning like, “Why does this person want to, whether it's an angel or a fund, invest in your fund?” Um, sorry, not fund… your company.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A reminder to vet investor motivation and alignment, not just terms, to avoid mismatched expectations later.

quotes.topic_title: Would Ryan raise again for Product Hunt
quotes.text: When you go down a certain path, when you raise a series A, B, C, like you have different expectations and when you raise your proceed or seed round. So I think also understanding like, you know, what you're signing up for is super important.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A mental model for fundraising as a path-dependent commitment where each round changes expectations and constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Are launches worth it and why launch
quotes.text: the thing about launching is- is going back to why are you raising money. What's the goal? Same thing. Why are you launching?
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Reframes launching as a goal-driven decision (like fundraising) rather than a default tactic.

quotes.topic_title: Are launches worth it and why launch
quotes.text: But sometimes that's actually not- it's not useful. Launch sometimes doesn't help with that, but there are many other reasons why you might wanna launch.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that launches often don’t drive acquisition and should be justified by other outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Are launches worth it and why launch
quotes.text: So, customer acquisition one, to get the word out. Another can be recruiting. So, by, you know, sharing your story, getting people excited, it might make it easier to recruit and get people excited about, you know, what you're building. Another is fundraising. Sometimes it can create momentum, you know, as- as other investors, they do read the news and they know that, you know, when this company is more public, they're might be more heat around it- a particular deal. Feedback is one. Um, the feedback from users, feedback just serendipitously and- and sort of another one is partnership. So, as you launch, you might also encounter more partnerships, more opportunities. I think there's a serendipitous effect of launching.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Provides a practical checklist of non-acquisition launch goals (recruiting, fundraising momentum, feedback, partnerships) and the “serendipity” upside.

quotes.topic_title: Are launches worth it and why launch
quotes.text: One of them is team morale. And this- this might- I think this is overlooked.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Highlights an underappreciated benefit of launches: internal motivation and cohesion.

quotes.topic_title: Are launches worth it and why launch
quotes.text: And, you know, somebody on the team can share, you know, the- the- the Product Hunt launch or, you know, some Tech Crunch article with their- their mom. And, you know, like that seems like a trivial kind of meaningless thing, but it actually matters for a lot of people.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A concrete example of how public launches create pride and celebration that can meaningfully boost team morale.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great Product Hunt launch
quotes.text: one- one thing I've noticed among founders and just people in general is they tend to write like a- a PR person and not like a human and not like, you know, the- the way that I kind of describe kind of a frame of- of writing, maybe your tagline for Product Hunt, um, or for your launch in general is like how- how do your customers or your users describe your product to other people? Or another frame is how do you describe it to your friends?
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Gives a practical framing for writing launch copy that sounds authentic and resonates more than PR-style language.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great Product Hunt launch
quotes.text: People see right- people are sick of the PR [laughs] speech. And so, I think the language and the microcopy, copyrighting matters so much.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Emphasizes that small wording choices can materially impact launch performance because audiences are numb to buzzwords.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great Product Hunt launch
quotes.text: And they probably not particularly interested in reading like an [laughs] essay, you know, from- from the makers. So, keeping that short, I think, is helpful.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Counteracts the common instinct to over-explain by recommending brevity in maker comments for skimming audiences.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great Product Hunt launch
quotes.text: And some of the most interesting presentations I've seen is people use the gallery almost like a slideshow, um, like telling a story, where each slide is- is communicating like a different- well, a story of some sort.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Offers a concrete tactic: treat the Product Hunt gallery as a narrative sequence to quickly communicate value visually.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great Product Hunt launch
quotes.text: some people, they ask me, "Hey, like I don't know, is Product Hunt like ... Do B2B companies do well there?" And I'm like, "Yeah, like a lo- m- probably more B2B companies than B2C companies actually,"
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Challenges the assumption that Product Hunt is mainly for consumer apps by asserting B2B can outperform B2C.

quotes.topic_title: PM background and investing advantages
quotes.text: I- I- having a product background, I think, is one of the most important aspects of early stage startup investing, meaning oftentimes, when you're building a new company, there are a lot of risks and there's a lot of important things to- to nail, but it all ultimately comes down to the product that you're building.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A clear investing heuristic: in early-stage companies, product quality is the core risk reducer and primary lever.

quotes.topic_title: PM background and investing advantages
quotes.text: And one, having more, I guess, perspective in evaluating different ideas and- and arguably more important, uh, how the founder thinks about things.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Shifts evaluation from the idea itself to the founder’s decision-making process—useful for both investors and hiring.

quotes.topic_title: PM background and investing advantages
quotes.text: So, it might be less about me evaluating the- the- the market need for this particular idea, but it's what's the thought process and how did this founder come to these product ideas and these insights.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A practical diligence method: interrogate the reasoning path that produced the insight, not just the pitch.

quotes.topic_title: PM background and investing advantages
quotes.text: And when it's early, early days, there- there's more opportunity to create some sort of impact or, you know, help shape the product in- in a slight way.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Highlights a tactical advantage of early-stage involvement: investors/operators can materially influence product direction.

quotes.topic_title: Rebuilding Product Hunt: focus, monetization, delegation
quotes.text:
I severely underestimated how difficult it would be to do two things: one, the product experience on Product Hunt is very different than how you would wanna discover video games or maybe, in the future, fashion and a bunch of other types of products out there.
And two, it's really difficult to translate a community and expand into other communities.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A concrete warning that “horizontal expansion” often fails because both the UX and the community dynamics don’t transfer across categories.

quotes.topic_title: Rebuilding Product Hunt: focus, monetization, delegation
quotes.text: So, that's one- one regret is we should not have tried to expand horizontally. We should've just focused entirely vertically and- and served the tech community, you know, better and- and with more things, which is effectively what we're doing now.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A clear strategic prescription: go deeper in one core market before attempting to broaden into adjacent ones.

quotes.topic_title: Rebuilding Product Hunt: focus, monetization, delegation
quotes.text: what I really should've done is dedicated maybe 10% of our focus on revenue generation because, you know, it was- once we started generating revenue, we- we did so very quickly, and we go to cashflow, break even, I wanna say a year, maybe 12 months after we started generating revenue.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A practical allocation heuristic (10% focus) plus a specific outcome (cashflow breakeven in ~12 months) that argues for monetizing earlier.

quotes.topic_title: Rebuilding Product Hunt: focus, monetization, delegation
quotes.text: up until shortly before I left, I was editing the newsletter every morning, for example, like every morning. I was waking up, you know, 5 a.m., 5:30 a.m., editing the newsletter. I mean that's just kinda silly, you know, to be doing that so many years later after starting.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A vivid example of founder over-control showing why delegation becomes essential as the company scales.

quotes.topic_title: Rebuilding Product Hunt: focus, monetization, delegation
quotes.text: you also just can't scale yourself nor are you the best person at everything.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A memorable reminder that founder quality standards don’t justify bottlenecking execution—scaling requires letting others own outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Hardest founder lessons and the CEO mask
quotes.text: Oh, yeah, there's some times where I felt physically ill, many different moments in- in Product Hunt.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A concrete example of how founder stress can manifest physically, underscoring the real cost of high-pressure periods.

quotes.topic_title: Hardest founder lessons and the CEO mask
quotes.text: Being a CEO or a founder makes it slightly harder in some ways because you still have to put on this mask.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Highlights the leadership “CEO mask” dynamic—projecting confidence even when you don’t feel it.

quotes.topic_title: Hardest founder lessons and the CEO mask
quotes.text: You have to put on this face of confidence externally and- and internally as well, where people need to trust you.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that trust often depends on leaders maintaining confidence both outwardly and in their own mindset.

quotes.topic_title: Hardest founder lessons and the CEO mask
quotes.text: You- you also don't wanna subject them to the same anxiety that you're feeling and be 100% transparent.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A counterintuitive take on transparency: leaders may need to filter emotions to avoid spreading anxiety through the team.

quotes.topic_title: Hardest founder lessons and the CEO mask
quotes.text: So, it didn't break me, uh, it just scarred me a little bit but didn't break me.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A memorable reframing of resilience that acknowledges lasting impact while emphasizing survival and growth.

quotes.topic_title: What matters most: relationships and momentum
quotes.text: I care less about having a lot of friends and more about a few deep, close relationships.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A practical prioritization principle: invest in fewer, deeper relationships rather than broad networking.

quotes.topic_title: What matters most: relationships and momentum
quotes.text: And even- even joining and- and being, you know, uh, in San Francisco in the tech community, you wanna meet a lot of people and network and all- do all those things, that- that's less interesting to me and less important.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A contrarian take that challenges the default “network more” playbook in tech communities.

quotes.topic_title: What matters most: relationships and momentum
quotes.text: momentum matters so much. And momentum is reflexive in that, you know, high momentum leads to more high momentum. Low momentum leads to more low momentum because there's this energy that- that kinda goes through companies where, when there is momentum, when people are shipping, when things are going well, other people feel that energy, and they wanna do the same, but in the reverse, someone who might be slowing things down, not shipping, not really performing very well, that actually does the reverse too.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A mental model for company dynamics: shipping creates contagious energy, while stagnation spreads demotivation.

quotes.topic_title: What matters most: relationships and momentum
quotes.text: you- arguably, it's one of the most important things in early-stage startups.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A clear prioritization heuristic for founders: treat momentum as a top-tier early-stage objective.

quotes.topic_title: What matters most: relationships and momentum
quotes.text: You can invest in 100 companies, and one of those companies is probably gonna return three to five X in the returns of all the others, maybe combined in some cases.
quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.context: A concrete power-law data point that explains why outsized momentum and outcomes dominate portfolios.
